awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Prosodic Structure: An Integrated Empirical and Modeling Investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines how the prosodic structure of language shapes the articulation of spoken utterances. Speaking is a complex, uniquely human ability that relies on precisely coordinated movements of the speech organs (tongue, lips, jaw, soft palate, and larynx) and respiratory system. These movements produce sounds that listeners perceive and that convey not only the 'dictionary' content of the utterance, but also its prosodic content. Prosody organizes phonological forms into successively larger units or phrases, and renders certain syllables, words and phrases more 'prominent' (perceptually or rhythmically important) to the listener. Understanding the processes that shape prosodic structure and how these processes act to transmit this structure through coordination of the speech organs has profound implications for advancing our understanding of language processing and communication disorders, for improving speech technology, and for providing insights regarding the more general relationship between linguistic and cognitive operations.

The central hypothesis examined in this collaborative project is that the control processes governing temporal and tonal structure are intimately linked with one another. This linkage is viewed as emerging from the underlying motor control dynamics that coordinate the motions of the speech organs and guide speech production. In order to investigate this hypothesis, two additional open questions are addressed concerning the nature of the units that exist at different prosodic and prominence levels, and the relationships among syllables, prosodic feet, words and phrases: "What are the structural and articulatory-acoustic properties of prosodic feet?"; and "How can the relationships among the levels be best understood?" These questions are investigated through a series of articulatory studies--using electromagnetic articulography--and acoustic measurements that will examine: 1) how temporal and tonal properties interact at phrasal boundaries, 2) how temporal and tonal properties interact within and across all levels of prominence, and 3) how motor control dynamics shape the details of articulatory-acoustic structure at the foot level. These studies will be complemented by a series of computational simulations, which will serve the dual purpose of testing the project's hypotheses and guiding further developments of the prosodic component of the group's Task-Dynamics model of speech production.

por.por_cntn:
The following work has been completed in the past year of the project:

We continued our work on grammatical pauses. A follow up on our previous study (Krivokapić, Styler & Parrell 2020) has, as discussed in our previous report, tested the cognitive function of pause postures (PPs) and found that PP occurrence but not duration is affected by upcoming utterance length. The results are interpreted as indicating that PPs are related to planning, and that planning proceeds over a fixed scope and proceeds throughout a prosodic boundary. The manuscript has been written up for publication and is now published.

Data analysis is underway examining kinematic properties during pauses preceding speech in read and spontaneous speech. Specifically, we test the hypothesis that the movement preceding speech can be related to planning of the upcoming utterance, and identifying the function of these movements.

Furthermore, we conducted the evaluation study of focus structure that was reported as designed in our last report. 180 American English speakers participated in the study. Analysis is currently underway assessing the link between production (on the basis of the audio data that were used as stimuli in the evaluation study along with the corresponding kinematic data) and perception (via the judgments collected in the evaluation study) of prosodic prominence and focus marking. The results of this analysis will be prepared for submission to the International Congress of Phonetic Sciences 2023 (ICPhS 2023) and will be written up for a journal publication.

Relatedly, the kinematics of the hierarchy of prominence in American English is now being written up for a journal submission. Our findings show that the degree of kinematic effects (i.e., on the dimensions of kinematic duration, amplitude and velocity) varies as a function of focus type (unaccented following broad focus, unaccented following contrastive focus, accented with broad focus, accented with narrow focus and accented with contrastive focus). Although the kinematic dimensions reflect different number of degrees, the direction of the effect is the same across all: articulatory dimensions become longer, larger and faster as the type of focus changes from unfocused to focused and from broad to narrow to contractive focus). In parallel, our work on prominence structure in Greek is now published in the Journal of Phonetics.

Our work on the interaction of prosodic boundaries with prominence in Korean has yielded significant findings, showing that focus marking in Korean, which is an edge-prominence language without any marker of lexical prosody, operates similarly to stress, head-prominence languages, in that focus affects the phonetic profile of both phrase-final lengthening and boundary tone. The results on lengthening are now prepared for resubmission to the Journal of phonetics, and the results on boundary tones have been accepted to appear in the Proceedings of Speech Prosody 2022. Analysis of a second set of data assessing the factor of boundary tone composition (Korean allows a large range of multi-tonal boundary events) is in process and will be prepared for submission to the International Congress of Phonetic Sciences 2023 (ICPhS 2023).

Our collaboration with Caroline Crouch and Ioana Chitoran on syllabic structure that has uncovered novel evidence that sonority interacts systematically with articulatory timing. The results have been described a journal paper which is now fully revised and will be imminently resubmitted to the Journal of the International Phonetic Association. We have also extended this work to directly examine the timing between constriction gestures as a function of sonority shape in onset clusters (up to three consonants) in Georgian. This new sets of results indicate that Georgian syllables do not present the timing patterns expected in syllabic onset, and instead, a coda-like coordination is found. We have developed an account of these data by bringing together different dimensions of Georgian grammar (phonotactics, morphology and phonology) with principles that are proposed to be universal. These results will appear in the proceedings of Speech Prosody 2022, and are currently being prepared for a journal submission (80% complete).

We continued work developing novel dynamical models of the interaction of tone and intonation in African languages. In collaboration with Yubin Zhang and Annie Rialland, we have completed a statistical analysis of downtrend of f0 in Embosi declarative utterances using an extensive, publicly-available corpus. The results support the model previously developed on a more limited set of data. While Embosi has been described as lacking f0 downstep over time, the results show that f0 follows a systematic, parabolic time course that can be modeled using a free-fall dynamical system that results in a “hard-landing” (increasing acceleration towards end of the utterance). This pattern can be contrasted with patterns found in languages that have been described as having downstep in which f0 follows the “soft-landing” dynamics of exponential decay. A paper describing the finding will be written this summer and submitted to the Journal of Phonetics.
